Development of Novel Molecular Markers</value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Single</value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>241</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>Autoantibodies</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>232</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>81, 232, 238</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>232</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>The aims are organized in 4 subgroups: Aims 1-4 will identify the more informative antigen biomarkers for use on our microarrays. Aim 5 will identify the protein sequences in these informative cDNA clones. Aims 6-8 will provide validation on larger serum sample sets. Aims 9-10 will establish a format of the diagnostic suitable for collaboration with other EDRN components. Aim 1. Employ high throughput antigen cloning and identification of a suitable number of biomarkers to accurately identify invasive breast cancer. Aim 2. Use machine-learning techniques such as classification trees and neural networks to develop classifiers able to distinguish women with breast cancer from healthy subjects. Aim 3. Estimate the test characteristics (sensitivity, specificity, accuracy) of the antigen markers for distinguishing sera of breast cancer patients from control sera. Aim 4. Eliminate those antigen markers that cross-react with patients with nonmalignant breast diseases and autoimmune diseases. Aim 5. Determine the DNA sequence of the cDNA clones of validated markers. Aim 6. Validate the markers on larger sample sets. We will use antigen clones to detect serum antibodies in the BCPS serum set. We will perform a secondary analysis of the reaction of antibodies in the patients sera to identify whether there are antigen reactions indicative of a high likelihood of recurrence. Aim 7. Determine the accuracy of the test in sera prospectively derived from women who later developed breast cancer. Aim 8. Eliminate antigen clones that react with sera from people with other cancers. Aim 9. Prepare of purified antigen-containing proteins for the penultimate antigen diagnostic array. Aim 10. Perform internal and external validation tests with EDRN partners. </value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>We are using IgG molecules specific to cancer patients as a bait to clone antigens derived from phage T7 display cDNA libraries of mRNA from tumor tissue that we use as biomarkers for the early detection of cancer. In a sense we are using the immune system as a biosensor. The immune system elaborates antibodies which we detect as they react with the antigens we clone. The antigens are expressed and then robotically spotted on microarrays. The microarrays are treated with sera from other patients and the binding of IgGs in those sera is used to find the most commonly reactive antigens. We print replicates of thousands of antigens on the microarrays and analyze them with a two-color detection system. The patients' IgGs bound to the spotted antigens are detected using a secondary antibody against human IgG labeled with Alexa-647, a red dye. The second color provides a control for each spot. We use a monoclonal antibody to the N-terminal 11 amino acids of phage backbone protein onto which each antigen is cloned as a fusion protein. That monoclonal antibody is detected with an Alexa-532 (green dye) labeled antibody against murine IgG. The dye ratios provide a control for variations in spotting so as to quantitate the IgG binding to each clone using sera of each patient. We also have a negative control clone that contains no additional amino acids in the cloning vector. The dye ratios on the chips are normalized and those data used in a t-test using sera from patients and healthy controls. Those clones significant in a t-test are used on a validation set of patients and controls not including the previous training samples. The antibody binding data of those subjects in the validation set are tested using machine learning techniques such as neural networks and n-fold cross validation to determine the accuracy of the classifiers.</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>N/A</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>174 Research</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>As cDNA clones of diagnostic antigens are identified, they will be published and added to the EDRN website.</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>No</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Jul 31 2010 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Aug 2 2005 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Case/control</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>9</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Early Detection of Breast Cancer Using Autoantibody Markers</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>To identify large numbers of antigens that can be used to recognize the presence of cancer by detecting antibodies to tumor proteins in the serum of the test subjects. Our technology will provide an early detection test for breast cancer in asymptomatic women. We will use bioinformatics techniques to analyze these protein microarray-immunoassays to discriminate between cancer patients and healthy subjects so as to detect disease prior to standard diagnoses as well as discriminate patients with benign conditions or other cancers that might be a false positive in less specific assays.</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value>To date, we have devised an approach to cloning biomarkers that focuses on the goal of identifying breast cancer at Stage I. We have applied this approach to early stage breast cancer and have some preliminary data to indicate the technology is feasible. The goal of this application is to apply this technology to develop: 1) an early detection assay for breast cancer in asymptomatic women and 2) a novel prognostic approach for women with early stage breast cancer, a disease from which 25-30% of women will relapse in 5 years post diagnosis.</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Collaboration</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value>300 breast cancer Stage I/II patients with no recurrence; 200 breast cancer Stage I/II patients with recurrence; 200 late stage breast cancer patients; 200 patients with non-malignant breast disease; 200 patients with autoimmune disease; 400 healthy control serum donors with no history of cancer; 300 other cancers, 30 each from 10 different tumor sites.</value>!!<Identifier>242</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>30 breast cancer Stage I patients with recurrence 30 breast cancer Stage I patients with no recurrence 120 healthy control serum donors with no history of cancer</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>Autoantibodies</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>232</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>65, 86, 232</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>232</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>AIM 1: Eliminate nonspecific antigen biomarkers that cross-react with sera from patients with nonmalignant head and neck diseases, autoimmune diseases and other types of cancers. AIM 2: Validate this diagnostic strategy for early HNSCC detection based on pattern of serum immunoreactivity against the biomarker panel. AIM 3: Assess the use of this diagnostic strategy for early detection of HNSCC in collaboration with other EDRN and non-EDRN sites. </value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>We are using IgG molecules specific to cancer patients as a bait to clone antigens derived from phage T7 display cDNA libraries of mRNA from tumor tissue that we use as biomarkers for the early detection of cancer. In a sense we are using the immune system as a biosensor. The immune system elaborates antibodies which we detect as they react with the antigens we clone. The antigens are expressed and then robotically spotted on microarrays. The microarrays are treated with sera from other patients and the binding of IgGs in those sera is used to find the most commonly reactive antigens. We print replicates of thousands of antigens on the microarrays and analyze them with a two-color detection system. The patients' IgGs bound to the spotted antigens are detected using a secondary antibody against human IgG labeled with Alexa-647, a red dye. The second color provides a control for each spot. We use a monoclonal antibody to the N-terminal 11 amino acids of phage backbone protein onto which each antigen is cloned as a fusion protein. That monoclonal antibody is detected with an Alexa-532 (green dye) labeled antibody against murine IgG. The dye ratios provide a control for variations in spotting so as to quantitate the IgG binding to each clone using sera of each patient. We also have a negative control clone that contains no additional amino acids in the cloning vector. The dye ratios on the chips are normalized and those data used in a t-test using sera from patients and healthy controls. Those clones significant in a t-test are used on a validation set of patients and controls not including the previous training samples. The antibody binding data of those subjects in the validation set are tested using machine learning techniques such as neural networks and n-fold cross validation to determine the accuracy of the classifiers.</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>N/A</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>144, 143, 148, 140, 160, 147, 146, 149, 145, 141 </value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>Lung and Upper Aerodigestive Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>As cDNA clones of diagnostic antigens are identified, they will be published and added to the EDRN website.</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value>Mar 31 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Mar 31 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Apr 1 2007 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Case/control</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>9</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Proteomic Approach for Diagnostic Applications in Head and Neck Cancer</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>To evaluate the test characteristics of a panel of biomarkers for identifying patients with early stage head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). The primary endpoints are sensitivity, specificity and accuracy of the marker panel. This study of the test characteristics of a modeling strategy for diagnosing HNSCC uses a case-control design, with several types of cases and several types of controls.</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value>We have demonstrated the feasibility of cancer detection based on analysis of patterns of serum immunoreactivity against a panel of cancer biomarkers selected using microarray-based serological profiling and specialized bioinformatics. Combining phage display technology with protein microarray, we screened 5,133 selectively cloned tumor antigens and ranked them using a feature selection method based on receiver-operator characteristic curves for neural network classifiers. A model, built using the top-ranked 40 biomarkers, was validated by bootstrapping on an independent set of 80 cancer and 78 control sera. Estimated accuracy of this modeling strategy was 83% (95% CI 77-88) with sensitivity of 83% (95% CI 74-92) and specificity of 83% (95% CI 75-94).</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Collaboration</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value>Sera from 200 patients with nonmalignant head and neck diseases; Sera from 200 patients with autoimmune diseases; Sera from 500 HNSCC patients (200 early stage and 300 late stage); Sera from 500 control patients</value>!!<Identifier>243</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>Sera from 200 patients with nonmalignant head and neck diseases Sera from 200 patients with autoimmune diseases Sera from 300 patients with other types of cancer Sera from 500 HNSCC patients (200 early stage and 300 late stage) Sera from 500 control patients</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>Prolactin, Leptin, IGF-11, OPN MIF, CA-125</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value>Ovarian Cancer (350)(Sensitivity Trial) : The disease group includes women having newly diagnosed ovarian cancer (pelvic mass). The study will be done using archived specimens if they meet the specimen collection protocol The diagnosis of ovarian cancer is done according to clinical, surgical, histological and pathologic diagnosis. The major histology groups (serous [borderline and invasive], mucinous, endometrioid, clear cell, and undifferentiated) will be represented proportional to their incidences. Preliminary communication with PLCO investigators indicates that the histological distribution seen in PLCO matches ours expected design. Within each histology, we will oversample early-stage disease where possible, with a goal of one-half early stage and one-half late stage. Control Group (1000)(Specificity Trial) a) Normal: The healthy control group includes age-matched healthy individuals, that come into the clinic for a regular gynecologic examination, who do not have a diagnosis of any type of cancer, or who are not genetically predisposed to develop ovarian cancer. This group is available from the PLCO and will represent the majority (80%) of the samples evaluated. Similar criteria will be used for samples collected from all the sites. b) High-Ris (50 samples): degree of risk is determined by formal genetic evaluation and categorized as mild (only one affected first-degree relative or a personal history of breast cancer), moderate (≥ 2 affected first degree relatives), or high (BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation inherited from an affected relative). It is estimated that over 50% of women with BRCA1 mutations that develop ovarian cancer are less than age 50. Women with a BRCA1 mutation have approximately a 30-40% risk of developing ovarian cancer by age 70. Also included in this group are women with non-gynecologic malignancies, gynecological malignancies other than ovarian, and benign gynecologic conditions(50samples). In addition we will include 50 samples from pati</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 167, 238, 266, 449, 450, 452, 453, 457</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>266</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value>2</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Aim 1. To validate the Yale Early Detection Assay (YEDA) in a Phase II Validation Trial consisting of a case control study for patients with ovarian cancer. Aim 2. To determine whether the Luminex platform and the inclusion of three additional markers will increase the sensitivity and specificity of the test. </value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>The concentration of the four markers will be measured in the serum using a sandwich ELISA. For the Phase II validation study all the tests will be performed by LabCorp, which has completed the process of validation and standardization of the four analytes. The Luminex platform will be evaluated at Yale. The specimen will be blinded to all labs on disease status. The blinded labels will be provided by EDRN/DMCC. The assay data will be sent to EDRN/DMCC. </value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>yes</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>183 </value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>Breast and Gynecologic Cancers Research</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>follow NCI guidelnes</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value>Jun 11 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Nov 1 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>May 1 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>3</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Ovarian Validation Study - Mor</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>While all cancer patients could potentially benefit from earlier detection and prevention, the development of new screening technologies and chemoprevention for epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) is unique in this regard. EOC is characterized by few early symptoms, presentation at an advanced stage, and poor survival. Presently there is no commercially available test that is diagnostic for either early or advanced stage epithelial ovarian cancer. The most commonly used marker, CA125, identifies a group of cell surface glycoproteins, which have uncertain biological behavior and very limited clinical utility for the detection of early stage disease. In recent years, several approaches have been used in order to develop a test for early detection, including the analysis of serum samples by SELDI-TOF and MALDI-TOF to find proteins or protein fragments of unknown identity that detect the presence/absence of cancer. Unfortunately, at the present time, none of these techniques have been shown to be adequate. Therefore, the development of a test that can detect early stages of the disease could dramatically improve treatment success and long-term survival. We have developed a new blood test based on a different approach: 1) we used known proteins related to cancer biology, 2) we characterized these proteins with several different screening steps using samples obtained from both healthy and cancer patient populations, and 3) validated the results with different techniques. Using split point analysis with four markers, 96 out of 100 EOC patients (96%) were correctly diagnosed with ovarian cancer (including 23 of 24 patients with Stage I/II EOC). In the healthy group, 6 out of 106 individuals were diagnosed incorrectly (5.6%). Working in collaboration with the Early Detection Network (EDRN/NCI/NIH), we performed Phase I discovery study confirming the potential application of this test for early detection of ovarian cancer (Preliminary results). The main objective of this prop</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value>1613</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Validation</value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>244</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>Sera 454</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>454</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>To validate the diagnostic value of a panel of serum antibodies (cathepsin D, p53, cyclin B1, topoisomerase IIalpha, IGFBP2, CEA) for the early detection of colorectal cancer.</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>We will run ELISA blinded to case status, data along with our prediction of disease status for each sample, will be sent to EDRN-DMCC at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center for statistical analysis. DMCC already has the combination role from our preliminary study. Our preliminary data suggested that at high specificity 90%, sensitivity is 57%. With n=50 in each group, we have more than 80% power to confirm this level of sensitivity against an inferior sensitivity of 37% at 90% specificity comparing CRC versus normal controls. We understand that the reference set is not powered for definitive validation but to help prioritization. We did not have the data on patients with adenoma but the performance on early-stage CRC suggests that it is possible our marker panel could detection early lesions like adenoma,</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>153 </value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>G.I. and Other Associated Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value>Goodell V, Lu H, Delong J, Disis ML. Antibody Immunity to a Panel of Oncogenic Proteins May Predict Presence of Colorectal Cancer and Stage of Disease. Manuscript in preparation.</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>Follow guidelines set by NCI</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value>Aug 28 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Feb 6 2009 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Oct 6 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Other</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>3</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Colon Cancer Specimen Reference Set Application: Disis - University of Washington (2008)</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>The proposed study aims to validate the diagnostic value of a panel of serum antibodies for the early detection of colorectal cancer (CRC). We have developed a serum antibody based assay that shows promise in discriminating sera from CRC patients from healthy donors. We have evaluated two separate sample sets of sera that were available either commercially or were comprised of left over samples from previous studies by our group. Both sample sets showed concordance in discriminatory power. We have not been able to identify investigators with a larger, well defined sample set of early stage colon cancer sera and request assistance from the EDRN in obtaining such samples to help assess the potential diagnostic value of our autoantibody panel</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Project</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value>1. Assess the Classification Error of their prediction:
The data set they used for prediction of case/control contains 130 subjects and 30 of them are cases. According to their predicted probability, we classify a subject as a case if his/her predicted risk ≥ 0.5 and a control vice versa.
Classification Error= # of false prediction / total # of subjects=0.12.
2. When assessing individual markers performance, among 6 tumor markers, only catD showed some potential of discriminating cancers from polyps, and cancer from controls. None of the rest seems to be good.
3. When using their algorithm (2 methods), the single score calculated based on the Ag weights is significant at discriminating polyps from cancers and polyps from control (but in the reverse direction with polyps has lower score than controls).
4. We also did logistic regression with all 6 tumor markers. The risk models are doing well in terms of classification accuracy (cancer vs. control, polyps vs. control, and polyps vs. cancer). But after correcting for model Overfitting, none of them is significant.
The results are not as promising as that observed in your preliminary study but catD and p53 do identify a small subset of patients with high specificity. However this set is quite small, about 20-30% of cancer cases. Your prediction model picked about a bit more than 50% of cancers with about 70-76% specificity (see the tables in the file if we combined polyps and controls as non-cancer controls to calculate specificity). Your markers seem to be cancer specific and are not related to polyps. The marker panel is still premature for a large validation study. catD and p53 definitely are elevated for some cancer cases but their sensitivites are not high enough</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value>1. Assess the Classification Error of their prediction:
The data set they used for prediction of case/control contains 130 subjects and 30 of them are cases. According to their predicted probability, we classify a subject as a case if his/her predicted risk ≥ 0.5 and a control vice versa.
Classification Error= # of false prediction / total # of subjects=0.12.
2. When assessing individual markers performance, among 6 tumor markers, only catD showed some potential of discriminating cancers from polyps, and cancer from controls. None of the rest seems to be good.
3. When using their algorithm (2 methods), the single score calculated based on the Ag weights is significant at discriminating polyps from cancers and polyps from control (but in the reverse direction with polyps has lower score than controls).
4. We also did logistic regression with all 6 tumor markers. The risk models are doing well in terms of classification accuracy (cancer vs. control, polyps vs. control, and polyps vs. cancer). But after correcting for model Overfitting, none of them is significant.
The results are not as promising as that observed in your preliminary study but catD and p53 do identify a small subset of patients with high specificity. However this set is quite small, about 20-30% of cancer cases. Your prediction model picked about a bit more than 50% of cancers with about 70-76% specificity (see the tables in the file if we combined polyps and controls as non-cancer controls to calculate specificity). Your markers seem to be cancer specific and are not related to polyps. The marker panel is still premature for a large validation study. catD and p53 definitely are elevated for some cancer cases but their sensitivites are not high enough</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Single</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value>see description of colon cancer reference set.</value>!!<Identifier>249</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>Serum from 50 participants with colon adenocarcinoma; 50 with colonic adenomas; and 50 with an endoscopically normal colon.</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>CCSA-3, CCSA-4,</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>455</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value>See summary of Colon Reference Set</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>455</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>455</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Aim 1: Characterize the distribution of CCSA-3 and CCSA-4 values in a blinded set of serum samples obtained from patients with colorectal adenocarcinoma, colorectal adenomas, , hyperplastic polyps, inflammatory bowel disease and normal colons.
Aim 2: Estimate the ROC curves for discrimination between: patients with colorectal cancer versus others; colorectal cancer or adenoma versus others; colorectal cancer, adenoma, or hyperplastic polyps versus IBD; colorectal cancer, adenoma, or hyperplastic polyps versus IBD or normal. </value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>1.1   Characterize the distribution of CCSA-3 and CCSA-4 values in a blinded set of serum samples obtained from patients with colorectal adenocarcinoma, colorectal adenomas, hyperplastic polyps, inflammatory bowel disease and normal colons. Both CCSA-3 and CCSA-4 are reported as concentrations on continuous scales. Graphical displays and descriptive statistics will be presented by disease category. If the graphical displays indicate the with-population distributions are significantly, non-Gaussian, the values will be appropriately transformed. Analysis of variance will be used to test the null hypothesis (at a 5% significance level) that the means of the populations are equal.
1.2   Estimate the sensitivity and specificity for discrimination between: 1) patients with colorectal cancer versus adenoma, hyperplastic polyps or IBD; 2) colorectal cancer or adenoma versus hyperplastic polyps or IBD; 3) colorectal cancer, adenoma, or hyperplastic polyps versus IBD; 4) colorectal cancer, adenoma, or hyperplastic polyps versus IBD or normal. For each of the four tests, the sensitivity and specificity will be estimated assuming prevalence of 0.50 and equal false negative and false positive costs. The null hypotheses that sensitivity < 0.75 and specificity < 0.75 will be tested using a one-side exact binomial test at a 5% significance level; rejection of the null hypotheses constitutes an argument for advancing the markers to a full validation study.
1.3   Empirical ROC curves will be plotted for Tests 1-4. Optimal sensitivity and specificity will be estimated depending on assumptions about prevalence and the costs of false positives and negatives. Tests 1, 2 and 3 are of particular interest for clinical management, while Test 4 is more relevant for population screening.
</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>153 </value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>G.I. and Other Associated Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>Follow guidelines set in place by NCI</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value>Feb 25 2010 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Feb 6 2009 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Oct 6 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Other</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>3</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Colon Cancer Specimen Reference Set Application: Getzenberg - Johns Hopkins (2008)</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>The goal of this project is to confirm the early validation of CCSA-3 and CCSA-4 as biomarkers for the early detection of adenocarcinoma of the colon and rectum. </value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Project</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Single</value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value>Serum samples from 60 subjects with colorectal adenocarcinoma, 60 subjects with colorectal adenomas, 60 subjects with hyperplastic polyps, 30 subjects with inflammatory bowel conditions and 60 subjects with endoscopically normal colons </value>!!<Identifier>250</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>Serum samples from 60 participants with colorectal adenocarcinoma, 60 with colorectal adenomas, 60 with hyperplastic polyps, 30 with inflammatory bowel conditions, and 60 with endoscopically normal colons.</value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 67, 87</value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>67</value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Two prospective studies were used to collect samples to make this reference set. GLNE 001, (Preliminary Clinical Characterization of Serum, Plasma, and Urine Biomarkers for Colorectal Neoplasms) was a prospective, cross-sectional clinical trial to collect serum, plasma, urine, and common data elements on subjects undergoing routine screening colonoscopy or subjects undergoing surgery or endoscopy for colon cancer. GLNE 007 (Evaluation of Stool Based Markers for the Early Detection of Colorectal Cancers and Adenomas) is an on-going prospective, cross-sectional clinical to collect serum, plasma, urine, stool, and common data elements. In both protocols, subjects were undergoing routine colonoscopy (or being seen in surgery clinic for colorectal cancer) when the samples were collected. Samples were collected while the target lesions were still in place in the colon. Subjects were either normal (without adenomas or cancer), with pathologically confirmed adenomas or pathologically confirmed colorectal adenocarcinoma. Exclusion criteria for both protocols included known hepatitis C or HIV, ulcerative colitis, Crohnss Disease or IBD, history of cancer within 3 years, or genetic colon diseases including FAP or HNPCC. Samples were collected from 4 sites around North America.</value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>251</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>153 Early Detection Research Network: Biomarker Reference Laboratories</value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Collaboration</value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>259</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>GP73, AFP, SCCA, SCCA-IC, AFP-IC and PIVKA-II</value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 509</value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>509</value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>To evaluate biomarker performanceof SCCA, SCCA-IC, AFP-IC and PIVKA-II versus AFP in an out-side cohort of LC and HCC patients. Our hypothesis is that the performance of the investigated biomarkers is affected by the accuracy of patient criteria inclusion, and potential inaccuracy of serum storage. Therefore, the study we have already reported in the literature is not yet clear cut and conclusive, nevertheless, the data seem promising to be further investigated. Our goals is to clinically validate proposed biomarkers in an external sample population, with more stringent criteria of selection and of data analysis. The performance of each marker will be evaluate through a ROC (Receiving Operating Charachteristic) analysis determining the area under the ROC curve, sensitivity and specificity. A multivariate logistic model will be also carried out to evaluate the performance of combination of marker. </value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>So far the general attitude to investigating a biomarker has been to search for an ideal molecule with a high specificity and sensitivity. However, the reality has been very different and all the investigators have taken this as a negative result of the potential biomarker investigated. Nevertheless, there is growing evidence that HCC is a very heterogeneous type of cancer, in terms of epidemiology, etiology and clinical outcome. Therefore, we hypothesise that several biomarkers need to be investigated in order to properly address these differences. This hypothesis is based on a number of findings: 1) in different studies there was a high variability in terms of sensitivity and specificity of the biomarkers investigated, even in the case of AFP. 2) Other biomarkers such as DCP have been proposed by oriental authors, but poorly accepted in the west. 3) Some biomarkers may predict a particular clinical outcome of HCC, as in the case of DCP associated with vascular invasion. 4) Recently, we have reported that SCCA significantly improves the diagnostic accuracy of AFP, but only in viral-related disease. Some new data recently submitted show that in alcohol-related non virus related disease, SCCA does not play any role, while DCP has a better performance. 5) Recently, it has been suggested that tissue expression of SCCA represents an early event in the onset of HCC, being more expressed in dysplastic compared to regenerative nodules. 6) Consistently with these data, our preliminary data recently submitted, show that SCCA is more strongly expressed in smaller than in larger HCC nodules.
</value>!!<Identifier>267</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>All samples were blinded as collected through the DCP validation controls</value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>PCA3</value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value>Inclusion •Males greater than or equal to age 18 •Patient scheduled for prostate biopsy for any of the following reasons: oPSA >2.0 ng/ml oElevated PSA velocity (>0.4 ng/ml/yr) oLower PSA value with other risk factors for PCa (e.g.; family history) oPrior ASAP or HGPIN oAbnormal DRE o% free PSA <15% •Finasteride/dutasteride and other medications for BPH and ED are allowable but will be recorded Exclusion •History of PCa •Urine not collected post DRE prior to index prostate biopsy oBlood can be collected up to 1 month before urine oUrine can be collected up to 1 month before index biopsy •Index prostate biopsy with <10 cores and without extended template •Index prostate biopsy pathology report unavailable •Participating in an intervention trial for prostate disease •Prior surgical (open or endoscopic) or minimally invasive treatment (TUNA/TUMT) for BPH •Prior saturation biopsy defined as at least 30 cores •Prior prostate biopsy within 6 months •Prior PCA3 test performed for clinical purpose •Consented more than 3 months before index biopsy </value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 83, 87, 88, 125, 131, 142, 200, 203, 491, 510, 525, 526, 527, 528, 529, 546</value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>510</value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Primary Specific Aims
Aim 1:To evaluate the PPV of PCA3 for initial biopsy population and NPV of PCA3 for repeat biopsy population in a multi-center prostate biopsy cohort of men without prior history of prostate cancer
Aim 2:To develop a novel urinary reference set consisting of whole urine /urine sediment as well as plasma/serum necessary for future pre-validation studies of urinary biomarkers.
Secondary Aims
Aim 1:To evaluate the sensitivity, specificity, PPV, NPV, and absolute risk prediction by PCA3 alone and multiplexed with other biomarkers and clinical variables in the detection of prostate cancer overall, and in the detection of high grade cancer
Aim 2:To evaluate the correlation between PCA3 and prostate biopsy tumor grade
</value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>PCA3 testing of processed urine specimens will take place at John Hopkins University (Dr Sokoll) and Gen-Probe (Dr. Groskopf) (see Appendix 5). Testing will be performed and analyzed according to the method described by Groskopf(8). The Hopkins EDRN Biomarker Reference Laboratory will assay 100% of the samples and the Gen-Probe laboratory will assay 10% as quality control.
Processed urine specimens will be tested in duplicate at both laboratories with the PCA3 Assay on the Gen-Probe Systems. The calibration curve will be tested in triplicate and the controls will be tested in duplicate. The mRNA results for PCA3 and PSA for each subject must be generated from the same processed urine specimen tube. </value>!!<Identifier>274</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>All samples 515</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>515</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value>1</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Aim 1. To pre-validate assay performance in a high-risk clinical population from an alternate demographic. We intend to validate the predictive accuracy of our markers for clinically diagnosed lung cancer, identify the limits of the assay in individuals with benign lung disease, and determine marker specificity for lung vs. other cancers. Pre-validation will define performance in samples from an alternate demographic and generate classifiers with which to construct optimalperformance criteria that can be applied to class prediction for subsequent blinded analysis of a larger EDRN clinical reference set.</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>Samples were blinded at NCI-Frederick</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>162 </value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>Lung and Upper Aerodigestive Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>Lab Data will be analyzed by the DMCC and shared according the LCBG/NCI guidelines</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Mar 25 2010 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Mar 26 2009 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Case/control</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>3</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Lung Cancer Specimen Reference Set A (Full) Application: Hirschowitz - University of Kentucky (2009</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>We are continuing validation with two advanced objectives: 1) To evaluate assay performance for established lung cancer diagnosed in a clinical population 2) to confirm results that indicate this marker set may detect cancer and predict the onset of NSCLC prior to radiographic detection in a screened population.</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Single</value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>279</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>150 cases and 150 high risk controls w/lesions - Lung Set A pre-validation</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>KLK8, 11, 12, 13, and 14 </value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value>See Lung Reference Set A</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 68, 87, 158, 239</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>68</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value>1</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Aim 1. We will coordinate with the Lung Cancer Biomarker Committee to obtain aliquots of serum reference set A (i.e., Phase II validation set: 180 cases and 180 controls, 75 other cancer controls). The characteristics of these sample sets have been described on the EDRN website. Aim 2. Two independent sites (UCLA and University of Toronto) will conduct ELISA tests on blinded serum samples for KLK8, 11, 12, 13, and 14. These assays have been well described previously, so we anticipate no technical hurdles. All samples will be run in duplicate. Aim 3. Data will be analyzed by the DMCC for both single KLK expression as well as for the entire panel (KLK8, 11, 12, 13, and 14) as previously described (1). </value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>Briefly, the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis test will be used to examine the relationship between KLK levels, pathology, and clinical information. To evaluate the KLK for disease screening and diagnosis, the classification accuracy will be assessed using receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves. The ROC curve will plot the true positive fraction (TPF) versus the false positive fraction (FPF) for the set of rules that classify a subject as test-positive i.e., if the marker value exceeds a threshold value, where threshold varies over all possible values. It quantifies how well a marker discriminates between diseased and non-diseased individuals. We will perform the ROC analysis first on individual KLK and then in combination. We will use an algorithm that renders a single composite score using the linear predictor, fitted from a binary regression model. A stepwise regression procedure will be used to select markers in the panel with or without additional clinical variables.</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>Samples were blinded at NCI-Frederick</value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>162 </value>!!<Identifier>280</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>Lung and Upper study will retrospectively sample tissue from patients who have undergone radical prostatectomy at the participating institutions. Each site will construct a set of validation TMAs containing tissue from a total of 105 cases of recurrent prostate cancer and 105 cases of non-recurrent prostate cancer. If resources allow, sites will construct a second set of discovery TMAs containing tissue from an additional 105 cases of recurrent prostate cancer and 105 cases of nonrecurrent prostate cancer.</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>EGFR, KRAS, CpG, TITF1 </value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value>Ever smokers: person who has smoked >100 cigarettes during lifetime; Never Smokers: person who has smoked less than 100 cigarettes during lifetime; Current Smokers: person currently smoking who has quit for > one year; former smokers: smoker who has quit smoking for > one year; long-term former smokers: smoker who has quit smoking for > 10 years; light smokers: smoker with total exposure of > 10 years.</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 74, 86, 87, 151, 420, 516, 517, 518, 519</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>74</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value>1</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Specific aim 1: Identify biomarkers of potential use for early detection/risk assessment of lung cancers arising in never smokers. Multiple platforms will be utilized by a team of highly experienced and competent investigators to compare and contrast the global and individual genetic alterations in lung cancers arising in current, former and never smokers. Appropriate samples or reagents from a set of already collected tumor and paired adjacent non-malignant lung tissues (or blood plasma) will be distributed to the investigators (Drs. Hanash, Gazdar, Lam and Sidransky). About 30 sets of samples from each group will be utilized. Platforms to be studied will include serum proteomics (Hanash), global messenger gene expression (Gazdar), mutations and copy number analyses for a selected set of genes (Gazdar), global copy number alterations using both SNP and aCGH platforms (Lam) and mitochondrial mutations (Sidransky). Data will be collected and analyzed at the DMCC (Mark Thornquist) and at the Vancouver site (Wan Lam) which has developed software for integration and analysis of cross-platform data. Specific aim 2: Confirmation studies on biomarkers identified in Specific Aim 1. Promising markers identified in Specific Aim 1 will be verified in preclinical studies by other platforms such as FISH and immunostaining using tissue and cell line microarrays, Western blots and qPCR gene expression studies, functional assays etc. After completion of the phase one of the validation process, phase two studies will be initiated. Specific aim 3: Perform phase three validation studies. Markers identified by the DMCC as showing promise after completion of phase 2 studies will be proposed as candidates for EDRN supported phase 3 validation studies.</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>FISH, qPCR, mass spectrometry, gene expression, ACGH, SNPS, methylation, microRNA</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>All specimens are blinded at the DMCC.</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>162 </value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>Lung and Upper Aerodigestive Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>Make data available for all EDRN investigators. After publication, make data publicly available to scientific community.</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Sep 15 2011 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Sep 15 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Case/control</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>1, 3</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Canary Never Smokers</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>The overall goal of this project is to identify, verify and apply biomarkers for the early diagnosis or risk assessment of lung cancer in never smokers. The first year will be regarded as a year of discovery. After successful demonstration of the feasibility of the approach for novel marker discovery, funding will be applied for to perform confirmation and preclinical studies on the biomarkers and validation studies (specific aims 2 and 3, to be performed in years two and three). Year two can be regarded as the year of confirmation and year three as the year of validation. </value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Collaboration</value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>282</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>28 biopsy with blood collected prior and serum stored at -70C for up to six years prior to analysis.</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 87, 200</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>200</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value>1</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>Specimens were analyzed in a blinded fashion at Beckman Coulter, Inc. on the Beckman Coulter ACCESS 2 immunoassay system for PSA, free PSA, [-2]proPSA, BPSA and testosterone. The PSA assays are all dual monoclonoal sandwich assays using Hybritech antibodies and chemiluminescent detection system. The assays for PSA, free PSA and testosterone are commercially available which the assays for [-2]proPSA and BPSA are for research use only.</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>yes</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>185 </value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>Prostate and Urologic Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>follow NCI guidelines</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>Yes</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value>Sep 15 2006 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Feb 1 2007 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Feb 1 2006 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>3</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Prostate Rapid Reference Set: Chan/Beckman (2007)</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>Evaluate performance of [-2]proPSA as an early detection marker for prostate cancer</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Project</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value>1360</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value>There was no difference in total PSA concentrations (non-cancer: 6.80+/-5.20 ng/mL, cancer: 6.94=/-5.12 ng/mL) between the groups. Overall %[-2]proPSA had the greatest area under the curve (AUC=0.69) followed by %fPSA (AUC=0.61). For %[-2]proPSA, maximal sensitivity was 60% and specificity was 70%. A logistic regression model combining PSA, BPSA, %fPSA, %[-2]proPSA, %[-2]proPSA/BPSA, and tesosterone had an AUC of 0.73. In the 2-10ng/mL PSA range %[-2]proPSA and the model had the largest AUC (0.73). The AUC for %fPSA was 0.53. Specificities for %[-2]proPSA, the logistic regression model and %fPSA at 90% sensitivity were 41%, 32% and 18% and at 95% sensitivity were 31%, 26% and 16% respectively.</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value>There was no difference in total PSA concentrations (non-cancer: 6.80+/-5.20 ng/mL, cancer: 6.94=/-5.12 ng/mL) between the groups. Overall %[-2]proPSA had the greatest area under the curve (AUC=0.69) followed by %fPSA (AUC=0.61). For %[-2]proPSA, maximal sensitivity was 60% and specificity was 70%. A logistic regression model combining PSA, BPSA, %fPSA, %[-2]proPSA, %[-2]proPSA/BPSA, and tesosterone had an AUC of 0.73. In the 2-10ng/mL PSA range %[-2]proPSA and the model had the largest AUC (0.73). The AUC for %fPSA was 0.53. Specificities for %[-2]proPSA, the logistic regression model and %fPSA at 90% sensitivity were 41%, 32% and 18% and at 95% sensitivity were 31%, 26% and 16% respectively.</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Collaboration</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value>123 men without a prior biopsy or prostate cancer history. 51% cases and 49% controls.</value>!!<Identifier>284</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Planned</slot><value>50/50</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>BiomarkerName</slot><value>GP73 and fucosylated markers against AFP, AFP-L3 and DCP as well as test them in combination with these markers</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Coordinating_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Eligibility_criteria</slot><value>Sample Eligibility defined in DCP Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Involved_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>5, 66, 87</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Lead_Investigator_Site_ID</slot><value>66</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_5_Phase_Status</slot><value>1</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Aims</slot><value>Directly compare GP73 and fucosylated markers against AFP, AFP-L3 and DCP as well as test them in combination with these markers</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Analytic_Method</slot><value>For data analysis, Receiver Operating Curves (ROC) should be generated for the Gp73 and fucosylated kininogen either alone and in combination with AFP, AFP-L3 and DCP and the area under the curve determined (AUROC). No training sets will be required. Markers will be directly compared by their AUROC values and ranked accordingly. The following will be criteria for advancement of a biomarker status and further testing: Statistically significant with alpha = 10% AUROC improvement in the distinction of cirrhosis from HCC with the addition of marker(s) to AFP alone for the full set of samples OR in defined subsets, e.g. AFP negatives, early tumor stage. The ultimate target is to find a combination of markers that will improve on current AFP-alone sensitivity and specificity, such that we will be able to achieve > 90% sensitivity and > 85% specificity for the distinction of cirrhosis from HCC. </value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Blinding</slot><value>All samples were blinded as part of the DCP protocol and then blinded during the sub-aliquot process at CLASS Lab</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Cancer_Type</slot><value>155 </value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Collaborative_Group</slot><value>G.I. and Other Associated Cancers Research Group</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Comments</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan</slot><value>According to EDRN guidelines data will be shared through public portal.</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Data_Sharing_Plan_In_Place</slot><value>No</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish</slot><value>Mar 16 2009 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Finish_Estimate</slot><value>Mar 17 2009 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Date_Start</slot><value>Apr 15 2008 12:00AM</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Design</slot><value>Case/control</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Field_of_Research</slot><value>3</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Name_Abbrev</slot><value>Liver Reference Set: Block (2008) (Rapid)</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Objective</slot><value>The goal of this application is to determine if the levels of serum GP73 and fucosylated kininogen/acute phase proteins can be used to detect hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the background of liver cirrhosis. The use of the validation set would allow us to directly compare GP73 and fucosylated markers against AFP, AFP-L3 and DCP as well as test them in combination with these markers</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_or_Project_Flag</slot><value>Protocol</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Publications</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Results_Outcome_Secure_Site</slot><value></value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Protocol_Type</slot><value>Single</value>!!<Identifier>285</Identifier><slot>Sample_Size_Final</slot><value>50
